qas.question: When was the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center constructed?
After which decade did modern styles give way to Gothic styles on campus?
In what year was Owings contracted to develop a second master plan?
What was Eero Saarinen contracted to develop in 2011?

plausible_answers.text: north and south of the Midway

qas.question: The third master plan led to the construction of buildings where?
In which year was the Gerald Palevsky Athletic Commons developed?

context: <a0_1>After <a0_0>the <b5_0>1940s<b5_0/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, the Gothic style on campus began to give way to modern styles. In <b6_0>1955<b6_0/>, <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>Eero Saarinen<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> was contracted to develop a <b7_0>second master plan<b7_0/>, which led to the construction of buildings both <b8_0>north and south of the Midway<b8_0/>, including the Laird Bell Law Quadrangle (a complex designed by Saarinen); a series of arts buildings; a building designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe for <a2_2>the university's <a2_0><a2_1>School of Social Service Administration<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>;, a building which is to become the home of <a3_2>the <a3_0><a3_1>Harris School of Public Policy Studies<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> by Edward Durrell Stone, and the Regenstein Library, the largest building on campus, a brutalist structure designed by Walter Netsch of the Chicago firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Another master plan, designed in 1999 and updated in 2004, produced the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center (<a4_0><a4_1><b9_0>2003<b9_0/><a4_1/><a4_0/>), the Max Palevsky Residential Commons (2001), South Campus Residence Hall and dining commons (2009), a new children's hospital, and other construction, expansions, and restorations. In 2011, the university completed the glass dome-shaped Joe and Rika Mansueto Library, which provides a grand reading room for the university library and prevents the need for an off-campus book depository.
